messages.text:
I am not taking in any case about reducing rates for Diamond tier. 

But for example having 14% YLD APY for 50K YLD holders and 16% YLD APY for 100K holders. 

Diamond user would not be loosing value but there would be incentives for people to hold more YLD driving the price up.

Cryto is all about momentum. How do you think YLD makes money? Doesnt fall from trees.

If you can not adapt to the market you are dead. 

Tiers should be mutable.

I understand you dont wanna loose your status because you only hold 20K or less than 50K, which i do too.

But im looking at an overall benefit for everyone, not just mine.

If those above 100K YLD are making 16% thats fine for me, im still making 12% with 20K YLD. 

But YLD price will go up.

messages.text:
This brought with it inevitable redundancies and job losses across the board. While devastating in the short term, this opens up an opportunity for talented people to move on to better things, while providing companies like ours with fertile ground to hire the very best talent. 

We have taken advantage of this, with 36 new hires brought on board in the last 12 months, and we don‚Äôt plan to stop here. Together with these new recruits and a solid team of incumbent world-class experts, we are well on our way to building the world‚Äôs leading comprehensive digital wealth platform. 


This is my favorite part of Tim's last message

messages.text: Looking forward to the AMA tomorrow. I can see a lot of emotions and much we need to clarify. We are now in the R&D stage now. Overall we are building our own Layer1 to address a lot of the issues we see in DeFi. We do realize by converting YLD holders to Haven1 there would be dilusion. There will be a balance of how do we bring on strategic backers for Haven1, reward our community who helped us get here with YLD holders, incentivize the top builders to come build on Haven1, and dozens of other reasons. We will try to address most in the AMA tomorrow, and will continue to roll out information over the next year. We have a dedicated team to build Haven1 that will not constrain our resources with Yield App. From my view point the future is brighter than ever. The possibility of having a major Layer1 ecosystem token that is also our membership token is very exciting to our team. As always we appreciate the support and feedback!

text_entities.text: Looking forward to the AMA tomorrow. I can see a lot of emotions and much we need to clarify. We are now in the R&D stage now. Overall we are building our own Layer1 to address a lot of the issues we see in DeFi. We do realize by converting YLD holders to Haven1 there would be dilusion. There will be a balance of how do we bring on strategic backers for Haven1, reward our community who helped us get here with YLD holders, incentivize the top builders to come build on Haven1, and dozens of other reasons. We will try to address most in the AMA tomorrow, and will continue to roll out information over the next year. We have a dedicated team to build Haven1 that will not constrain our resources with Yield App. From my view point the future is brighter than ever. The possibility of having a major Layer1 ecosystem token that is also our membership token is very exciting to our team. As always we appreciate the support and feedback!

messages.text:
The Haven1 blockchain is (quoting also from YA Team member Akash):

- permissioned 
- regulated (central authority can invalidate transactions; freeze withdrawals)
- mutable (transactions can be rolled back)
- KYC is baked in at the transaction level

That might rock some people‚Äôs world, but this is essentially Tradfi with a blockchain and token thrown in

If you‚Äôre going down the route of permissioned + regulated + trusted central authority, you don‚Äôt actually need a blockchain at all

===

We overcollateralise in Defi because in the absence of a trusted authority (and mutability of transactions) there is no other way to build in a safety margin for lending to unknown counterparties

This is not a bug, it‚Äôs a feature. Move away from permissionless, trustless transactions and you‚Äôre no longer in the world of crypto/Defi - you‚Äôre back in TradFi, and TradFi gets on just fine without blockchains

So it looks to be superfluous. Like a solution in search of a problem

messages.text: Why come up with a new token that will inflate more over time? It had a fixed supply for a reason. Now everyone has a part of the FIXED yld supply and it suddenly gets replaced by a token that is going to inflate even more in the future and loses value because of the emissions. It all gets backed by more use case *in the future* blabla. The emissions of the new token would affect the value anyway. It would be better to keep the max supply the same so early YLD investors (which made you this possible) would not get affected by the inflation of the H1 token. Aside from this financial/token perspective I must say Yield app does a great job of managing the bear market so far with their rates and product (and not going bankrupt lol). The idea of the blockchain is nice but revise the tokenomics of the new token, so early YLD investors don‚Äôt get affected by suddenly new tokenomics. It‚Äôs basically saying that our investment is going to lose value due to more inflation in the future what was not planned in the first place.

messages.text:
I think everyone needs to chill for a little lol. Haven itself is great news for everyone. Your tokens will have a lot more utility and and YA can tap into a much larger pool. 
Dilution is never nice but necessary to make that new chain a success. Ecosystems are expensive to bootstrap.
Also personally I believe there is a lot of harsh premature judgment for the incomplete information we have at this point. Let's continue this discussion until after ama tomorrow. Don't be afraid to ask the harsh questions there and get satisfying answers.

messages.text:
Couple of things. 
1. Join the AMA and I think as a community you‚Äôll be pleasantly surprised what we have been building and trying to evolve into
2. The reality of the industry post Terra/Luna, 3AC, Voyager, BlockFi, Celsius > FTX and what happened during FTX collapse to the whole industry is what is forcing us to make some pretty big bets on how to survive and navigate what has become an increasingly hostile environment - crypto industry has become a ghost town when it comes to liquidity, credit lines are pulled, there‚Äôs zero trust and there are now two very distinct camps. Crypto native trying to be nostalgic and Insto/TradFi that had finally come off the sidelines and now shut the door on the industry as regulators come
After every retail focused platform out there

text_entities.text:
Couple of things. 
1. Join the AMA and I think as a community you‚Äôll be pleasantly surprised what we have been building and trying to evolve into
2. The reality of the industry post Terra/Luna, 3AC, Voyager, BlockFi, Celsius > FTX and what happened during FTX collapse to the whole industry is what is forcing us to make some pretty big bets on how to survive and navigate what has become an increasingly hostile environment - crypto industry has become a ghost town when it comes to liquidity, credit lines are pulled, there‚Äôs zero trust and there are now two very distinct camps. Crypto native trying to be nostalgic and Insto/TradFi that had finally come off the sidelines and now shut the door on the industry as regulators come
After every retail focused platform out there

messages.text:
Yieldapp distributed the yield token saying there would be only 300m ever created and 20k would be highest Tier.
People bought the tokens speculating on prices appreciation,given those tokenomics...
If the h1 token is to replace yield token,how is yieldapp holding up this deal?
Would it not be possible to create a yield token on haven1 and burn the yield token on ethereum if nessessary?
That would uphold yieldapps promise and keep buying pressure for the yield token by retail customers using yieldapp.
It looks to me, as If yieldapp is  trying to gain institutional customers without demanding yield token holdings by those institutions.
This depreciates the value of yield Tokens and puts the interest of institutions and yieldapp before holders of yield Tokens and  retail customers already invested in yieldapp.
I hope the yieldapp Team upholds promises and tokenomics made in the past.
Cheers!

You said earlier that you'd rather lose money than be lied to.

As a victim of a company that
lied to me

took my crypto from me (and another company that did not lie, but took my money anyway), I find it very very hard to empathise with this statement, to put it mildly üòõ So I'd rather be lied to but keep my crypto üòÑ So please please, Yield App, lie to me as much as you can, as long as you keep my sweet APY and my crypto SAFU.

Anyway, H1 is not even launched yet, nothing has been converted, diluted yet. So what lies are we talking about here? There was the announcement, everything is a work-in-progress, feedback is being collected. Maybe in 1 year we'll get dilutted and/or screwed in one way or the other, who knows. But as of today, Yield App stands as one of very few (relatively :P) trustworthy CeFis out there.

Contrary to many other players that did not know how to pivot or how to manage risk.

BTW I cannot recall any other company where you could directly talk to CIO (or CEO) and discuss the company matters to such extent.

messages.text:
Sapta. Considering much of what was talked about in the AMA I'm left with an overwhelming feeling that HNW clients are YAs main focus, and that retail makes up only a small % of the total AUM. With this in mind, would it be a good option to retain YLD for retail and allow those who wish to transition over to HA1 to do so if they wish. From a % angle it is the small investors who own the most wallets with YLD in, and who stand to lose the most with a forced transition. Give people the option and you keep everyone happy, whilst still pushing ahead with the upgrades required to better service HNWIs and Institutions. 

Please pass this message along to Tim/ Justin and Lucas.

Thank you

messages.text:
FTX and Celsius changed the game.
However, I do believe at some point retail come back and convenience is always appealing.. (It's human nature, my uber eats charges can attest to that).  When they do, Yield App will still be offering the same service as we do now, along with all the additional features and polish that will have come by then.  

In addition to that, Yield App will have a higher standing in the space by association with Haven1 and the companies that build there, along with other partnerships that are in the works right now. Lastly we will have stood the test of time and be one of those companies that "has been here since 2021 and survived the bear market".  That's bullish for retail user growth on the platform when the time comes and all of which should benefit us plebs far more than only being what we are now.

messages.text: Personally, I am thankful that the YA team is being proactive to make a necessary pivot as clearly dictated by market conditions.  All my friends that I introduced to YA have pulled their assets out due to the fear that came out of last years debacles.   This retail sentiment towards CEFI  is not going to change anytime soon and even if it does, regulators are going to make operating earn products in its current form impossible.  Working on the new direction must happen now as maintaining the status quo and waiting for brighter days n a bull run in 1 or 2 years from now will remove a pivot as an option if the return to past glory never comes.

messages.text:
Haven is much needed change. Without it, YA (and thus out tokens) would die a slow death. Cefi Earn will never be back to the same extend as it was pre Ftx and Celsius. YA and yld would have continued to be in the twirling muddy waters the ruined reputation of cefi earn left. Let's face the facts, with YA's earn program alone, our yld tokens would have never ever gone back to old highs. Not even close to those. With H1, our tokens don't only have a fighting change, the scope of the project increased manifold, and with that our potential for token appreciation. 
In addition, finally the token has a use case (more than one actually) which incentivises to hold more than 20k (to earn more network fees). That's amazing news and is barely discussed here. 
The token dilution is unfortunately necessary. Ecosystems are expensive to bootstrap. But without an active ecosystem, no one will use H1, hence no fees are being generated, hence our tokens would earn less from fees. Our share in the pie shrinks, yes. But the pie will get so much bigger, so that eventually our smaller piece of the new pie is a lot bigger than our larger piece in the old pie

messages.text:
I agree that there is still a lot of information missing. YA had to make a choice: be transparent and announce H1 as soon as possible with as much info as they have atm,
Or build this is secret while telling the community nothing and then present the final build without giving us the opportunity to give feedback and make suggestions. 

By being transparent and sharing early, we have one year to discuss with YA and share our feedback, make recommendations, and perhaps even change the outcome of the chain design to our advantage.
Being presented the final result would have limited to no voice at all.
Now which option would you prefer?

messages.text:
What we are facing now is an objective dilution - even Tim has admitted that

Whereas what you are counterposing this objective devaluation with is some hazy promise in the future. Maybe it‚Äôs a rocketship, maybe it doesn‚Äôt get off the ground

I can‚Äôt say, I don‚Äôt have a crystal ball, but the main thing is I wasn‚Äôt asked whether I wanted to buy into this promise. The decision was made while all my YLD are still locked from the original promo

I put my money in YLD because I believed in the concept of the platform and had confidence in the team. If that turned out to be a bad bet because Cefi platforms ultimately have no future then so be it - my money, my loss - but I was investing money on the basis of *that* idea, not something radically different altogether

What we have now is more like a bait-and-switch
 
I have zero interest in putting money into some Orwellian, permissioned, KYC‚Äôd blockchain. Maybe it excites other people but to me it‚Äôs not why I came into crypto. It‚Äôs more like the stuff of nightmares. I‚Äôd sooner buy shares in GS or JPM than plough money into this

messages.text:
Your statement is your own and of course you are entitled to it but it is a quite dramatic and ignoring a lot of issues that face us, YA and the industry.  They could have hid this from you and rugged us if they were really nefarious.  
What would you have them do?  Ride the YA train as it was into a wall which is where most CEFI projects have gone in the last year.  Again its a perspective thing, you can look at it as a bait and switch or a resourceful move to attempt to circumvent dire market conditions due to a Tsuanmi of failures and debacles in the CEFI space recently to save the project. They are not getting rid of YA but creating a contingency path in the event things dont work out.  

Please read this from W4lker, couldnt have said it better myself

"I agree that there is still a lot of information missing. YA had to make a choice: be transparent and announce H1 as soon as possible with as much info as they have atm,
Or build this is secret while telling the community nothing and then present the final build without giving us the opportunity to give feedback and make suggestions. 

By being transparent and sharing early, we have one year to discuss with YA and share our feedback, make recommendations, and perhaps even change the outcome of the chain design to our advantage.
Being presented the final result would have limited to no voice at all.
Now which option would you prefer?"

Your statement is your own and of course you are entitled to it but it is a quite dramatic and ignoring a lot of issues that face us, YA and the industry.  They could have hid this from you and rugged us if they were really nefarious.  
What would you have them do?  Ride the YA train as it was into a wall which is where most CEFI projects have gone in the last year.  Again its a perspective thing, you can look at it as a bait and switch or a resourceful move to attempt to circumvent dire market conditions due to a Tsuanmi of failures and debacles in the CEFI space recently to save the project. They are not getting rid of YA but creating a contingency path in the event things dont work out.  

Please read this from W4lker, couldnt have said it better myself

"I agree that there is still a lot of information missing. YA had to make a choice: be transparent and announce H1 as soon as possible with as much info as they have atm,
Or build this is secret while telling the community nothing and then present the final build without giving us the opportunity to give feedback and make suggestions. 

By being transparent and sharing early, we have one year to discuss with YA and share our feedback, make recommendations, and perhaps even change the outcome of the chain design to our advantage.
Being presented the final result would have limited to no voice at all.
Now which option would you prefer?"

I use that already thanks. In fact, I was using Compound and Curve before discovering Yield. messages.text:
I was a presale investor in Yield, have been accumulating Yield since day one, top 100 holder and VIP, here are my thoughts on the recent info:

1) I think drawing in HNW and institutional clients is a good idea, and if YA team think haven1 is the best way to do that then I trust them.

2) I was very disappointed by the projected (not set in stone) dilution of YLD to H1‚Äôs possible 1 billion supply. Tim said multiple times the max supply of YLD will always be 300M and now it feels this has been changed by the backdoor.

3) I am glad they seem receptive to feedback. Changing tokenomics is a sensitive issue, often divisive and runs the risk of community deterioration (e.g. losing trust). I hope all feedback will be carefully considered.


I am struggling to see why YLD must be converted to H1 for this to work. Why not offer the option, i.e. anyone who wishes to convert YLD to H1 can do so when the time comes or keep the swap channel open (or offer an airdrop, e.g. for every X YLD one locks/stakes they get 1 H1) and keep YLD as the token tied to Yield App, i.e. same tiered system.

text: Hi

,
I just wanna give my 2 cents after all these announcements.

First of all, I'm quite enthusiastic about the new plan / project.
I think the Yield App team has a very good expertise and understanding on the financial / cryptocurrency industry. So I'm very confident that if you decide to go for this new project, you know what you're doing.

During the last year, a lot of events (pretty bad events for the most part) happened, and you still managed to keep our funds safe, while delivering great yields for us. And for that you earned my absolute respect. Yield App is all about security from the start, so I think you know what you're doing with this blockchain project.

Today, I believe that YieldApp needs to be better known and recognized, and this new project could be a good way to achieve that. I really hope Haven1 will bring mass adoption to the table.
Also, I think this might be a good way to face all the challenges provided by all the regulations to come.

With that being said, I think the YA Team needs to take into account the feedback of the community (and you did it in the past so thank you for that).
After reading all the telegram groups (Official TG, French TG, etc...), I think the main issue here for the people is the dillution of our tokens.
We all know you need to do this for a reason (mostly bring other players into the table, because you need money and investments to achieve this new project).
But maybe you can meet us halfway, with some sort of system that can bring more satisfaction / happiness to the loyal people here.

For example, instead of doing the 1:1 conversion from YLD to H1, maybe you can think about something like this :
Diamond: 1:1.5
Gold: 1:1.3
Silver: 1:1.2
Bronze: 1:1.1
No tier : 1:1

This is just an idea, but maybe you can look into it, think about it, and come back to us with a proposal ? I know we have 1 year before the release of this new project, so maybe we can work together to find a solution that works for everyone ?

P.S : Also, to all the people here who groan in a violent way, I know you're angry but there are people behind the screen, and they always answer our questions at any time during the day, even during the week-end sometimes. This is all about constructive criticism :))

messages.text:
One way to look at the dilution situation could be to consider Yield App as a hot dog stand, outside Wallmart.
If you own 10% of that got dog stand and then Wallmart merges with it, you don't own 10% of Wallmart now, but you will surely earn a lot more from your share in that hot dog stand.

Haven1 is the Wallmart here. If we assume for a minute that the research and consultation Lucas, Rhys and their respective teams have done over 2022 will bring prosperity, we want all YLD holders (of which we all are as well), to benefit. We could just build Wallmart separately and and not disturb the status quo, but we strongly believe that the direction we have chosen will be best for everyone, while making this huge endeavour possible.

In the meantime everyone is earning 20% extra tokens each year, increasing their holdings as a reward for being here early and we have all of 2023 to develop the details and work on the final tokenomics etc.

text.text: I think Haven1 will not be a blockchain that will make a whole lot of sense for the average crypto investor.

text:
The yield app team are trying to build a blockchain that will be mainly used by institutions and maybe ‚Äûqualified Investors‚Äú.and those people will be dealing mainly amongst themselves. It is planned to be a proof of authority blockchain.
Profits on this blockchain will naturally go to the parties that are important to it‚Äôs function.
Being proof of authority this will be the validators(not token holders).
Those will be professional,heavily vetted institutions.
They will want to be paid for this service.
Parties developing or running swap/trading services on chain can charge fees.but again,that won‚Äôt be token holders.
Governance? Why would they design a blockchain for institutions only to have governance in the hands of some retail token holders?why pay for that?governance has to do what the institutions want or they simply won‚Äôt show up.
Transaction fees?why would anybody who uses this chain,want transactions to be expensive?
And why would anybody that actually uses the chain want those fees to go to tokenholders?
My bet is,that over time token price, fee structure and profits will naturally gravitate towards the participants who provide the most value.
Validators,defi-protocols,vetting services, maybe insurance or other services will make money.
As a prospective token holder I have no idea why my token would go up in price or why I should earn yield for holding this token.
That being said,I have full confidence that the yield app team can pull this off!they really seem to be at home in both the finance industry and crypto.
But I doubt that they can design this blockchain for institutions in a way that will be a great investment for retail investors.
The Value of yieldapp ,for me ,lies in steady returns and good risk management.
With the yld token,I thought I could buy access to this Value on the cheap and later sell it for a profit.
That was my reason for holding more than 20k yld.
I still believe that this Value is there and can be bought and sold, if we keep yld.
But if yield app designs haven1 with h1 token holders in mind it might just not be as good as it could be‚Ä¶

messages.text:
They begin a new project, and want the new token to have a non-zero value from start.
This is nice to show to new H1 (institutional) users.
Otherwise, it would look as an airselling attempt to them. As anyone can print tokens out of thin air, but not many want pay a penny for them.
Every client costs the company some money on average. It may turn out that managing ordinary users has little to no profit. Thus, institutions look always more attractive to deal with. Also they are picky and won't talk to newcomers. I.e. YA had to play with small fish first, and move on toward the YA's dream. Even though, it requires to arrivederci with early adopters.
YA has built a team of professionals over the past 2 years, and all of them want a cozy place with less stress and more stability.
This is a great time for them to try in b2b sector, because not many competitors have survived around

messages.text:
Can I just say one thing to the team if you are there. Lucas, Tim and Admins‚Ä¶ You guys are obviously sharp and know this market well, better than 99% of people here. You have weathered the storm and we are still standing, and I appreciate you have been dealt some unprecedented events with FTX etc, and you need to respond and adapt to them which you are doing. I have faith that you are trying your best, however the only thing I need to say is-

You MUST, and I mean MUST look after your early investors who have been accumulating yield and propping up your ecosystem up till now. You MUST give them a fair swap into the new token. I‚Äôm not saying 1-1 as we don‚Äôt know the tokenomics, and of course if the pie is bigger then the piece will be smaller. But you really MUST reward and look after your initial investors and early people- not leave them high and dry. 

Is that fair enough?

messages.text:
blockchains generate value and yield, because they have a vibrant ecosystem and usecases and provide utility to a big community. protocols like uniswap utilize this and generate yield on those blockchains.

Creating a totally new blockchain, that would be able to generate billions in value, so that institutions could extract yield out of it,would require a totally new ecosystem with hundreds of usecases, and companies and protocols on top and millions of users.
If you want this, you are competing with dozens of other blockchains.
it‚Äôs almost sure that you won‚Äôt be able to create an ecosystem, that will provide enough utility, to generate millions in fees.

i understand the wish/need of institutions, but the wish does not generate an ecosystem of hundreds of projects‚Ä¶

so i don‚Äôt get it‚Ä¶

messages.text:
I hope so, I love the challenge. This past 12 months has definitely taken its toll and made me question the whole crypto ecosystem- I‚Äôve never seen such a complete cluster fuck of an industry in such a short period of time. I had hoped that our announcement re Haven1 and Digital Wealth would have been better received, but honestly sometimes I think people can‚Äôt see the woods for the trees.

Retail investors on earn platforms are going to be regulated into oblivion that means YLD ->>> 0. We are all fked as YLD holders. So we tried to build something that has real world value if we pull it off that can generate real interest and growth and we thought it would be smart to give our YLD holders access at the start as opposed to abandoning YLD to regulatory Armageddon and only working on things that generate fees and revenue for us

messages.text:
The blockchain itself can generate enough volume for multiple users to need H1 to trade on it.
If you need H1 for everything implemented on H1 the price of H1 will rise.

You can make fees from token swaps. 

You can make a ton of fees if they actually create a derivatives platform.

You can make fees from trading vaults ( that they will finally create) and they will have top class funds managers wanting to use secure vaults to trade.

My question is how much of that share will H1 token holders make. That fees can be made is a non brainer.

messages.text:
Chainlink, Cardano, Solana, Uniswap, Polkadot, and all the rest dropped 90+% in token value in 2022.  Did you want us to buy back more than the 50m+ YLD we already bought back while also staying afloat while adhering to our dedication to capital preservation and risk management?   

And your comment about how everyone would have been just fine, trying to talk down our efforts in 2022.
I guess it's rhetorical at this point but why show much complete contempt towards Lucas and behave like the whole Cel, FTX, Luna, 3AC catastrophe was no big deal. 

I know from my personal communications with a huge amount of our community back in late 2021/early 2022 that we saved many from Luna, some left to go get 20% but got out in time entirely because of our warnings from 3 months before anyone else was alarmed.

messages.text:
I've read your messages, I think it would be helpful for you to consider that Haven1 is an additional project, being built by a separate team.  Yield App as you know it, will indeed continue with it's existing offerings and development.  I myself tested structured products today and am blown away by how good it is and fiat is closer than ever.

Just because the YLD token will benefit from the buildout of Haven1 in 2024, that does not mean that Yield App stops doing what it's doing.

messages.text:
It's best to just consider Haven1 a bonus that has the potential to put Yield App on the map.  

If we just announced: "Yield App is X days away from Fiat and Y days away from structured products, etc, enjoy the great unlock!" -  There would have been no pitch forks and people would have still dumped/ not dumped/ whatever.

However...
Our Defi team, who are undoubtedly at the top of their field, have seen the opportunity to innovate and position us strongly into the future.  And we decided to share what we have come up with so far - 12 MONTHS ahead of time, to give everyone a chance to make whatever decisions they feel most comfortable with ahead of the next lock up cycle.

The feedback, ideas and criticism is all very welcome and that's why we have this chat. The blatant disrespect and baseless mud slinging however is not. It honestly breaks my heart to see someone like Wendy, who's only contribution in 2022 was to make sure anyone who came into this Telegram knew we were a shit company (as if that will help his tokens go up), while someone like Lucas slept under his desk at times to make sure that no one here ever lost a cent.

They didn't just make this up on the back of an envelope. I would encourage people to listen to what Rhys and Lucas shared in the AMA.

messages.text:
In the immediate term, fiat rails and structured products are on the horizon.  These are not small endeavours.  Afterwhich the team does not suddenly abandon Yield App and pivot to Haven.  Haven is a separate team, building in parallel. 

There will be more building going on at Yield App in 2022. We have grown to about 70 full time staff, there's a lot of work going on and more updates will roll out as the year goes on.

messages.text:
I had hoped I could just ignore the Haven1 news as something irrelevant to me and go on as usual without caring about what it is. But I am looking at the latest AMA now and this is totally heartbreaking. You can almost hear in the voices of the staff presenting that they dont want this themselves and they know it could well be the end of yield app.

Ive been using yield app since the start in 2020. And having the YLD value completely decimated by suddenly tripling the supply and thereby hurting loyal customers who have already endured a 95 % YLD price drawdown whilst at the same declaring that the company will now attempt to create some L1 that no one asked for is pretty much the worst possible news. Masquerading the whole thing as "community-driven" etc. also gives off some serious Alex Mashinsky vibes.

The main thing that kept me bullish on YLD throughout the bear market was the low supply of the token. Now thats gone too. This feels like the mother of all backstabs. Diluting the purchasing power of the users by increasing the token supply is just like the shenanigans banks do in regular finance. This is the polar opposite of what crypto is supposed to be about

messages.text:
I just wanna add something (because when in stressful times we often talk about the negative but rarely the positive): 
 
This year when all CeFi competitors blocked withdrawals, YA did not block anyone. 
This week, new stress test with the fall of the token (mass sale) + all the pissed off people who withdrew their funds from YA: again no blocking from YA, everyone was able to withdraw. 
 
We can say what we want, but when the big behemoths of the CeFi experienced a wave of withdrawal, it was carnage. YA has had several stress tests on his side, and they have never taken the decision to block people's funds, and they are still standing (and in addition they are recruiting when all the others have had to fire staff). 
 
It proves a certain robustness in the YA model.

messages.text:
-i apreciate you reading my comments!
-i wanna make clear, that i am in it for the money. i either want a good yield product or a token that gives me additional benefits and value or both. as i don‚Äôt build the tech at yield app, i am in for my benefit as 100% of all the other people.
so i would be more than happy, to see H1 do a 100X, yield app providing audits and merkte trees and giving me yield. i am not against this.

-i am just pointing out inconsistencies and problems. the more inconsistencies and problems i see, the less i invest in yld/h1 and the less i trust and use yield app. i know that others think the same.

-you are not obligated to answer me any question, but if you want your community behind you, you should of yourse try to be transparent and answer questions.

-maybe you tried, but i still haven‚Äôt gotten any answer to my core concerns. 
1.Why do we need a new blockchain with a new token that will fund (as your said) your new blockchain. There are blockchains that you could use and the only argument i heared is the commingling of funds. There are blockchains where you could prevent this. and you, as yield app, could be a middle man, that garanties there is no commingling.
2.How do you want to bring value to another blockchain. there are dozens of existing chains that have a hard time to generate real value, yet you want to create the 101 L1 blockchain. Sorry, but i haben heard any argument, how you want to bring value to the chain.

conclusion for me:
I will keep my yld-status and i won‚Äôt sell.
but i also won‚Äôt buy any more and i won‚Äôt use the platform any more, up until it‚Äôs clear how you want to bring value to the chain and why you are doing it.
but as i said: i hope H1 does a 100x, cause i will be very happy.

text: I will try to answer some of your questions.

text.text: "my main concern is, that they are this dilution for building another blockchain that nobody needs and without being clear how they will attract hundreds of projects, millions of users and millions in TVL."

-In the AMA, the team discussed how the need was identified, not only by virtue of the fact that we clearly have a world class understanding of regulation and defi but also through consultation with leaders in finance who are unable to engage with DeFi in its current state.
"it‚Äôs insane. there are other blockchains trying this since years and now yieldapp has the enlightenment to joins this race "
- As per the AMA, we were unable to identify any suitable solutions.
- This was just a single example I gave to try and demonstrate one of many use cases because I personally have had interest from gaming studios in what Haven1 provides.
"yes, let‚Äôs use the intranet‚Ä¶it‚Äôs a great idea!!!"
"So if the team is this awesome and all is fine, please explain me, why you are not just expanding on you original vision."
- As stated over and over again here, we are.

"Now, your goal is 10x easier achievable. almost ALL competitors are gone.
i can think only of 2 left. binance and cake.defi. So your could, as cake did, gain hundreds of thousands of users from the other platforms."

- Sadly Celsius and FTX going bankrupt did not make our goals 10x easier. Also, I think you just offended Nexo and Swissborg there, but I can tell you that Celsius customers, for exmaple, are not banging down the doors of CeFi platforms right now.
"you could build in the bear and thrive as THE staking and yield app in the next bull."
- We are. Haven1 in no way takes away from the existing plans of Yield App.
"So please give me one logical explanation, why this awesome model, in which you are now one of the few kings, is not good enough and needs now a blockchain."

- You're right, Yield App is an awesome model and has proven to be, as you say, good enough to serve the needs of its clients. We are not going anywhere and continue to build. Soon you will see this with structured products and proper fiat rails along with more announcements over the course of the year. Haven1 is a separate project with its own team, Yield App will continue to build as intended regardless.
"sorry, but this is ridiculous and you know it."
- So we know our plans are ridiculous but have decided to do it anyway? Perhaps I should borrow one of your facepalm emojis.
"that‚Äôs why i haven‚Äôt been given a logical answer to my questions."
- Logical answers have been provided on repeat in this chat over the last 48h and also in the AMA.

text:
Even your friends at Cake DeFi seem to be happy to provide logical answers for you:
"According to U-Zyn Chua, CTO and Co-Founder of Cake DeFi, the firm will scale its transparent and trusted paradigm by introducing Cake DeFi Enterprise to offer a secure gateway to decentralized finance for institutions. A significant increase in business inquiries over the past year, indicates a need for institutional DeFi services." 

Further insights are available in the the AMA and some also find it helpful to do a search in this chat for posts by Lucas to get some more of his direct answers here. I am confident that our team of proven experts, in consultation with the biggest names in tradfi have what it takes to understand and be on the forefront of blockchain finance into the future.  And if you don't, that's ok... The world has changed, the next cycle will not be like 2021. However the one thing that is certain, Yield App, as you know it, isn't going anywhere.

messages.text:
No worries.  Take some time to digest the info, the AMA was a good one, Tim, Lucas and Rhys are incredibly sincere people.  I joined Yield App because I've never met a team who are as talented as they are genuine. 

I remember 6 months ago this telegram blew up when Lucas said that all these audits are bullshit. Looking back now, you see that he was just trying to be sincere with our community and it was only months later that everyone realised he was right.

Rhys flagged Luna more than 3 months before ANYONE doubted it. Again, we got tremendous pushback saying that it's ridiculous for us not to support UST and that we have failed our clients by not offering 19.5% APY when they can get that safely on Anchor.  Again, in time we were proven to have the vision and tried to bring everyone with us.

I remember when we first dropped rates around Dec 2021, people straight up accused us of just ripping customers off to get more profit for ourselves, despite the fact that we were able to clearly demonstrate that real yields in DeFi basically halved overnight using publicly available data. But nothing we said was enough for some.  Now it's obvious that we were simply protecting clients by not taking on additional risk and dropped rates because rates dropped, simple as that.  These actions are appreciated now, in the wake of all the ponzi schemes and so on. But time and time again, our actions are misunderstood but proven to be sound down the road. Not saying we haven't got plenty of room to improve, our failure to deliver certain features on time etc has been extensively discussed, but I can say that our intentions are always good and on the critical stuff, we have been right.

If you have a question that starts with the premise that we are "moving away from generating yield.." please hear my voice like a little bird on your shoulder.  Yield App, as you know it, as you expected it to be, shall continue with our stated goals and business model. 

We have grown over 2022, we have a more professional, experienced team than ever. One of these teams will be building Haven1 without it taking anything away from the core business as you know it.

text_entities.text:
No worries.  Take some time to digest the info, the AMA was a good one, Tim, Lucas and Rhys are incredibly sincere people.  I joined Yield App because I've never met a team who are as talented as they are genuine. 

I remember 6 months ago this telegram blew up when Lucas said that all these audits are bullshit. Looking back now, you see that he was just trying to be sincere with our community and it was only months later that everyone realised he was right.

Rhys flagged Luna more than 3 months before ANYONE doubted it. Again, we got tremendous pushback saying that it's ridiculous for us not to support UST and that we have failed our clients by not offering 19.5% APY when they can get that safely on Anchor.  Again, in time we were proven to have the vision and tried to bring everyone with us.

I remember when we first dropped rates around Dec 2021, people straight up accused us of just ripping customers off to get more profit for ourselves, despite the fact that we were able to clearly demonstrate that real yields in DeFi basically halved overnight using publicly available data. But nothing we said was enough for some.  Now it's obvious that we were simply protecting clients by not taking on additional risk and dropped rates because rates dropped, simple as that.  These actions are appreciated now, in the wake of all the ponzi schemes and so on. But time and time again, our actions are misunderstood but proven to be sound down the road. Not saying we haven't got plenty of room to improve, our failure to deliver certain features on time etc has been extensively discussed, but I can say that our intentions are always good and on the critical stuff, we have been right.

If you have a question that starts with the premise that we are "moving away from generating yield.." please hear my voice like a little bird on your shoulder.  Yield App, as you know it, as you expected it to be, shall continue with our stated goals and business model. 

We have grown over 2022, we have a more professional, experienced team than ever. One of these teams will be building Haven1 without it taking anything away from the core business as you know it.

messages.text:
after listening to ama and reading all the messages on discord/telegram I still have a few questions (correct me if I got some facts wrong):

1. As someone already mentioned why not do airdrop haven tokens to YLD holders, but instead merge YLD into haven?
I know you need some capital for haven, but YLD as of now has 12million market cap. 12kk market cap is much less in "cash" than 12kk. Ama mentioned you have raised 40kk recently, that's many times more than all YLD worth.
Merging YLD into haven mostly just moves 1/3 value to current YLD holders and 2/3 to new pockets.
So merging YLD into haven adds only a few million $ (up to 12 by current prices) to haven for incentives etc, but creates a shitstorm from the community, because people feel they lost 2/3 of their YLD value.
Imo not worth angering all the community for this little gain in capital.

2. Maybe it's just me, but I still can't understand the concept of permissioned/kyc blockchain. Why exactly is it better than just using databases like traditional finance?
I just googled randomly "blockchain advantages" and it gives me these points:
Immutability - no, because haven transactions can be reverted
Transparency - yes
Censorship - no, because haven has AML etc
Traceability - no/yes, haven is a blockchain, but transactions can be reverted

messages.text:
Thanks for your questions. On the first one, in reality, it's not quite as simple as it would appear on paper. It's not like in 12 months from now, overnight we suddenly get 12m out of thin air.  The new supply will run to 2028 - a longer emission than the current token and worth remembering that is 6 years away. The impact of this inflation is being highly overweighted against the potential case for new growth and we hope to see all YLD holders benefit from this growth.  As someone else pointed out in here, even the most dormant Layer 1 tokens have a market cap 10x higher than the YLD market cap. I'm not going to extrapolate that into price talk, but it puts it into perspective I think.

We don't intentionally anger the community. I say it all the time, but our interests are aligned, none of us get special treatment, if we win, you win. I know it's a clich√© but it's just it's true.

On the second point, the litepaper is a good starting point but I would add that a database can not hold digital assets. Haven1 could, for example, be the base layer for gaming assets, property, etc. As a huge NFT degen myself, I believe the tokenisation of everything will happen a lot faster than people think and I look forward to seeing how we can be a part of that.

messages.text:
Before September we offered daily liquidity only, but had allocated some funds at 14 days notice monthly liquidity. Because of the massive number of redemptions we withdrew the majority of capital back to the platform to facilitate redemptions as we weren‚Äôt going to gate or halt withdrawals. What happened was only 30% of the withdrawals remained lost most coming back instantly or within a couple of days. 

We discussed this in an AMA in the summer and 70% of our capital moved to Earn+ at the request of the clients and that aligned more with our liquidity profile. We dropped rates for basic earn to address the mismatch

messages.text:
Can confirm as I posted a warning about this on another group on Nov 5, right at the start of the weekend, and I was directly affected 

BTC withdrawals were the first to get jammed because FTX had a policy of sending all users‚Äô BTC straight to BitGo to exchange it to WBTC, and then letting Alameda degen trade the shit out of it using their unlimited margin 

On Saturday and most of Sunday you could still do stuff like USDT transfers out on TRC, but BTC was extremely hard to get confirmations for, so the surest way was to cash it out to stables and then withdraw 

By Monday even USDT withdrawals were getting stuck

text: and also

would be cool if you could join the discussion:

i‚Äôll refer to your answers:

1.‚ÄúIn the AMA, the team discussed how the need was identified, not only by virtue of the fact that we clearly have a world class understanding of regulation and defi but also through consultation with leaders in finance who are unable to engage with DeFi in its current state‚Äú

-you did not answer my main point. my point is, that a blockchain does not work like: I have capital and i want to deploy it, without commingling (the need is there).So let‚Äôs create a blockchain to deploy capital and extract yield and maybe the blockchain will be used by people who need to use this blockchain and give value to later‚Ä¶
It must be the other way around. You have a blockchain that is used by millions and because they use it, and pay fees and need services, you can start to deploy capital. And my thesis is, that you won‚Äôt be able to create a another blockchain, that wil be used by hundreds of projects and thus generate yield.
There is no need of projects for another blockchain. all projects can find a home and find existing alternatives to heaven. The only entities that would need this blockchain are entities that have money and want to deploy it without commingling but this is not enough. it‚Äôs no usecase.




2.‚Äúwith the hopes of attracting games "
- >This was just a single example I gave to try and demonstrate one of many use cases because I personally have had interest from gaming studios in what Haven1 provides.

-yes, one single example, but it shows that there is obviously no vision. Cause it‚Äôs 100% sure that a gaming studio does not need/want heaven. I can name you at least 5 existing blockchains that are awesome for gaming. so no there will be no gaming companies migrating to heaven

every usecase you can name, is able to find existing solutions. gaming, nft, payment, ‚Ä¶ so please tell me why hundreds of project should migrate heaven and make it valuable? Why?
Only usecase yet: i want yield/defi, without commingling. but this does not work. this is no usecase‚Ä¶


3.Sadly Celsius and FTX going bankrupt did not make our goals 10x easier. Also, I think you just offended Nexo and Swissborg there, but I can tell you that Celsius customers, for exmaple, are not banging down the doors of CeFi platforms right now.

-i don‚Äôt see nexo as a legitimate company, but yes, i forgot swissborg.
So you tell me, the evaporation of all competitors did not make yield apps goal 10x easier?
More developers, better reputation, more customers‚Ä¶you name it‚Ä¶
i know for a fact, that swissborg didn‚Äôt loose customers and cake gained customers.

So here we have exactly the main point of criticism.
If yield app doesn‚Äôt manage to gain out of the evaporation of almost all competitors, then they should put the effort into this, and not putting resources into a blockchain with a new token that dilutes existing users and provides new capital to the company (as said in the ama).


some thoughts maybe they help.

i hope yield app thrives and h1 will become a top 10 coin.
but still i have my concerns and the yld holders are the stupid ones‚Ä¶ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

i thought that people can read between the lines and understand, what somebody means, if he says ‚Äûnot a single one‚Äú‚Ä¶. there is ALWAYS an exception.
don‚Äôt look at how i phrase things, and obviously english is not my mother tongue.
look at what point i try to make.

and i am 100% sure (and with 100% i mean 99% üòâ), that if you are longer than 2 years in crypto, you know very well, 
1.speaking to teams or even making ‚Äûpartnerships‚Äú doesn‚Äôt mean much in most cases
and
2.we already have many very awesome blockchains for gaming, that work very well and have a vibrant ecosystem.

why on earth would any reputable gaming studio build on a blockchain, that is neither build nor proven.
and even if they want to.
building a game takes years.

so don‚Äôt search for the single little flaw in my argumentations.
look at the bigger point i am making:
-creating a blockchain with millions of users is so hard and the competition is years ahead
-taking resources and putting them into this side project does not make much sense for some people from the outside
-those people, like me, try to understand where the sense is, but even if you tried (what i appreciate), i don‚Äôt get the usecase and the vision.
-and once again: i would love to get it, cause then i would double down on yld and be happy to be in a project earlier, that can make a 100x.

all people i talked to, sold in the last days most of their yld.
i hold, but i don‚Äôt double down yet.

messages.text:
The studios I've spoken to have expressed a desire to avoid re-inventing the wheel in terms of security of their assets. The biggest concern for them is that their players get hacked (which is why I used the Axie example earlier). Haven1 prevents a safeguard for that. They also like that by existing on our blockchain they will be compliant. They also see that Yield App's team has a strong record on security, generating real yields as well as staying ahead of regulation with our highly experienced compliance team. Yes building games takes years, we are planning to hang around for years.
That is why on earth. I can't comment on what happens on other planets.

Again, in terms of the competition being years ahead, I've answered you twice on this and it's also answered in the AMA and litepaper. We looked for competition and did not find any, hence we are building this ourselves.

Again, in terms of all these resources being ripped away from Yield App to go into Haven1, I am honestly sure I've answered this a dozen times in the last 48h. The building of Haven1 will not put a tax on the plans of Yield App.

I terms of you not understanding the use case and vision, between the answers in this telegram as well as Tim, Lucas and Rhys in the AMA and the litepaper, it's all there. Perhaps take some time to go over them again and if you have specific questions, we'll be here.

I terms of you not understanding the use case and vision, between the answers in this telegram as well as Tim, Lucas and Rhys in the AMA and the litepaper, it's all there. Perhaps take some time to go over them again and if you have specific questions, we'll be here.

text:
Hi Adilus, when you have the chance, please take the time to watch the AMA about Haven1, the team discussed how the need for this new blockchain was identified, not only by virtue of the fact that we clearly have a world class understanding of regulation and defi but also through consultation with leaders in finance who are unable to engage with DeFi in its current state, why we'll need a much bigger supply for Haven1? it's because H1 is NOT only a membership token. It'll be a Layer 1 token that would bring much wider usecase/utility.

This supply of 1b is almost 6 years ahead of us, as mentioned by Pete more than a week ago:

There's much more to see about the announcement apart from the dilution, there's still a lot of things coming in 2023 before we announce the whitepaper, we just launched structured products, and we continue building.

text: As mentioned by Pete:

it's not quite as simple as it would appear on paper. It's not like in 12 months from now, overnight we suddenly get 12m out of thin air.  The new supply will run to 2028 - a longer emission than the current token and worth remembering that is 6 years away. The impact of this inflation is being highly overweighted against the potential case for new growth and we hope to see all YLD holders benefit from this growth.  As someone else pointed out in here, even the most dormant Layer 1 tokens have a market cap 10x higher than the YLD market cap. I'm not going to extrapolate that into price talk, but it puts it into perspective I think.

We don't intentionally anger the community. I say it all the time, but our interests are aligned, none of us get special treatment, if we win, you win. I know it's a clich√© but it's just it's true.

messages.text:
EVM has been in production for almost 9 years so we have decided to use EVM until roll ups mature, then become a roll up later. To take on new tech for something that's meant to be safe and secure as its primary focus doesn't make sense.

As Anthony said, we announced this at the earliest possible time to give everyone a heads up BEFORE the new lock campaign, precisely not to lock anyone in without understanding what we're working on.

I believe if you read the litepaper and watch the AMA you will get a lot out of it. Please don't hesitate to ask further questions here, of course and the search option here is also your friend.

Sometimes there are also just variables that, while known, have timeframes beyond our control. I suspect something like this would be one of them and I have no personal insight into what the legal framework around it might be in 12 months from now.

We do have really top compliance teams, and Justin loves paperwork... We embrace regulation and are at the forefront, it's just not something I could possibly estimate now.

messages.text:
Hello team, I am earlier investor in Yield app, i found the team transparent and hard working so far, if i could say one of the best team i saw in crypto, very cautious and responsible.  2022 has been a hard year for everyone so i understand many reply from Pete. but at the same time some replys got me quite confused.
I thought that the Yield app despite the token price, was doing relatively good as you still offer a decent yield return, you manage to escape the big fails of 2022 and (i hope) team was making some money .
Now some market recovery is happening and next bull run will be in 1-2 years.  I thought that you were ready to present your product Yield App (+Trofi now) to a wider audience, just probably needed to adjust the yields of tokens and tiers. so i dont understand:
-  why you are not waiting to see the ripe of the market and catch the right time for Defi. Your app is very good and the brand is out. Is the situation of Yield token so bad, that you were expecting value is going to 0? I mean many tokens are below the expectation, but thinking that your own token is a disaster, that s quite different.

I read about Haven and read many posts here from other community member, so i have some concerns about this big change of direction by the team as well.

i would like to ask:
1- whats the main problems have Yield App about regulations?   This is something that all defi world have to face soon or later 
2- to fully build a layer 1 project it takes 3 to 5 years, will you have enough fund for this long time?
3- it is not possible to keep haven as a product of yield app team, with just a new token and let Yield app going for its own road ? And Maybe let community have the choice of the swap. 
4- after few years you made up a solid community, why don t share this possible Haven idea and ask for opinions from community before take the decision?
5- I understood you made this decisions also confronting to other companies. did you already received some funds or made some partnership?
thanks.

I thought that the Yield app despite the token price, was doing relatively good as you still offer a decent yield return, you manage to escape the big fails of 2022 and (i hope) team was making some money .
Now some market recovery is happening and next bull run will be in 1-2 years.  I thought that you were ready to present your product Yield App (+Trofi now) to a wider audience, just probably needed to adjust the yields of tokens and tiers. so i dont understand:
-  why you are not waiting to see the ripe of the market and catch the right time for Defi. Your app is very good and the brand is out. Is the situation of Yield token so bad, that you were expecting value is going to 0? I mean many tokens are below the expectation, but thinking that your own token is a disaster, that s quite different.

I read about Haven and read many posts here from other community member, so i have some concerns about this big change of direction by the team as well.

i would like to ask:
1- whats the main problems have Yield App about regulations?   This is something that all defi world have to face soon or later 
2- to fully build a layer 1 project it takes 3 to 5 years, will you have enough fund for this long time?
3- it is not possible to keep haven as a product of yield app team, with just a new token and let Yield app going for its own road ? And Maybe let community have the choice of the swap. 
4- after few years you made up a solid community, why don t share this possible Haven idea and ask for opinions from community before take the decision?
5- I understood you made this decisions also confronting to other companies. did you already received some funds or made some partnership?
thanks.

text:
I share similar concerns. Reading in-between the lines I think they are doing this because:
1) they are seriously concerned about retail users being regulated out of cefi/defi platforms, potentially destroying yield app as it is.
2) thus they want to widen their offering to HNW/institutions, and they see a demand/opportunity for it anyway.
3) they know stimulating demand and price action of a new L1 token won't be easy hence they want to bootstrap (I e. Force) it on us yielders.

So far I see their logic and think this pivot adds value. I trust their team knows the market well.

Trust being the key word. Tim said multiple times there would be no more than 300M yld tokens and technically still true, it has been proposed (not set in stone) that H1 will have a billion supply.
This is where I disagree with them.
We all know what happened in 2022 and trust in cefi took a HUGE hit so to modify tokenomics now seems like a sleight of hand / backdoor way of doing things.
Short term this will hurt yld and this can be seen from the chart. Development costs for L1 will be high and they know it so they likely want to have more tokens in reserve to fund this but I know they know maths so 300M of a token worth 3.33x more than a 1 billion supply token is the same thing.
And hate to state the obvious but if tokenomics has been changed once who is to say it won't be changed again. Team has to carefully weigh options to minimise community damage. They seem open to feedback which is good, but proof is in the pudding, so we will have to wait and see.

That is why I offered some suggestions to mitigate some of the issues. I will link to it shortly.

Long term H1 could be very successful (and the team has a lot of yld) so incentives for all yld holders are aligned which is good but imho unless they have a few huge clients already lined up they will struggle to hit their $5 billion AUM target in 2025.

Personally I think there are pros/cons but this has increased my uncertainty and generally I tend to de-risk as a result so that's my current thinking.

messages.text:
thanks for sharing. I agree this should be a choice and not imposed from above. 
 I am few years in crypto and i see what happens: L1 projects before becoming fully functional, they takes years. other L1 even if good project they just fade away, very complex projects and take a lot of resources. So it is worth and safe jump from defi to L1? this i dont have enough data to say, i trust the team on this.
Also From YA team I understand that the crypto is  in continuous evolution and you need to evolute as well to survive as a company (see for example IDOs launchpad before and after bear market). As it is now it sounds to me that H1 choice has been made out of desperation instead of  evolution. Instead of keeping the core and  offering something new, they are going to change everything toward this new adventure, will be good or bad..who knows?
As investor this choice affect me a lot, as the development will take years, so i will hopefully see some return from my Investments in yield app token-H1 in probably 3-5 years from now. While the idea until 1 week ago was to see YA defi app used by lot of crypto users in 2024/2025 etc.. 
another point is: since apparently there is demands from institutions/HNW, why not getting funds already now instead of using investors'. because you know in 1 year things will be different and a company who is saying today "yes it is interesting" in 1 year thay can even forget the  project

messages.text:
I think there is a big difference with L1 projects of the last bear market who need VC's for funding their projects.
YA has a product who is "printing money" and has done very well in this huge collapse of 2022.
 I think structured products will give to YA more possibilities for their treasury.
Actual price of YLd is at a seed of private sale level.
Changing the tokenomics is a risk of course but also an opportunity to onboard big investors with for example a counterparty about a certain amount of liquidity in the 3 major products of Haven ( money market, AMM and derivatives plateform)
Concerning Haven blockchain,
It will be fully centralise, so if you think about blockchain trilema,  if you have less decentralisation, you could have more scalability which is a good point for a derivatives platform.
In the lite paper, it's write about having commodities (who is a very very big market)... and for the moment there is nothing like that in blockchain space.
It's quite easy to imagine, it  could be a cash fees machine.
I don't think this blockchain is from scratch, but a fork of something who will work as an ethereum side chain, and will opfully become a roll up.
I see a point about zk-proof KYC
This is some of my thinkings

messages.text:
First and foremost structured products carry a very different risk than earn products as ultimately the yield is being generated by the user not Yield App. For example, pretty much any enhanced yield generated in a structured products comes from either selling volatility, using correlation to increase the volatility you‚Äôre selling, adding credit exposure to get access to higher yields. 

Structured products generate yield by adding the user selling something to create that yield. If the user is wrong, then they lose and if they‚Äôre right, they gain.

It‚Äôs completely different to the way generate Yield in Earn. 

Yield in Earn and Earn+ has one and only risk, you take the counterparty risk of Yield App as an unsecured credit to us
